head.title: ü™ê Giant camera snaps space in HD

p.span: The Vera Rubin Observatory has just released its first cosmic images‚Äîcaptured by a digital camera so powerful it can spot a golf ball from 15 miles away.

Over the next decade, this observatory will scan the night sky repeatedly, uncovering hidden asteroids and distant galaxies. The question is: What new cosmic secrets might unfold when we view the universe in Ultra-HD?
World‚Äôs largest camera reveals deep space
Murati‚Äôs Thinking Machines Lab nabs $2B
China on the verge of ‚Äò100 Deepseeks‚Äô
Tesla robotaxis hit regulatory speed bump
Quick hits on other major tech news
Image source: Vera C. Rubin Observatory
The Vera C. Rubin Observatory, perched on Chile‚Äôs Cerro Pach√≥n, just
the first images from its Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST) camera ‚Äî the world‚Äôs largest digital camera, with a staggering 3,200-megapixel sensor.
These initial shots, generated from a mosaic of 678 exposures during a brief test run, showed millions of galaxies, stars, and unknown asteroids.
The LSST camera, roughly the size of a small car, is a marvel of modern engineering, designed to capture more detail than any previous telescope.
Its ultra-wide lens can capture an area 45 times the size of the full moon in a single exposure.
The LSST will run for 10 years, repeatedly photographing the entire southern sky every three to four nights, creating a time-lapse view of the cosmos.

Researchers now will be able to track everything from near-Earth asteroids to supernovae and the movements of dark matter ‚Äî without the usual bottleneck of telescope time applications. As the observatory ramps up, the sheer volume and quality of its data promise to transform our understanding of the universe.
Image source: Atomico/YouTube
Thinking Machines Lab ‚Äî the secretive startup founded by OpenAI‚Äôs former CTO Mira Murati ‚Äî just
a staggering $2B at a $10B valuation, marking what may be the largest seed-stage funding ever recorded.
The round was led by heavyweight VCs Andreessen Horowitz, with participation from Conviction Partners and other top-tier firms.
Murati, who led the development of ChatGPT and DALL-E, heads a team of about 30 engineers, nearly two-thirds of whom are former OpenAI employees.
With no public product yet, Thinking Machines Lab is banking on the reputation and vision of its star team to attract capital and talent.
The startup aims to solve¬†‚Äúblack box‚Äù AI¬†issues, prioritizing transparency and user control, a departure from opaque models that dominate the field.

For now, the startup‚Äôs astronomical valuation is less about what it‚Äôs built than what it might build ‚Äî a bet that this team, with its track record of delivering groundbreaking AI, can once again redefine the field. In a sector where talent is king, Thinking Machines Lab looks to be a major player in AI‚Äôs next evolution.
Image source: DeepSeek
China is on the verge of a major AI boom, with a former top official predicting that the country will see more than 100 DeepSeek-like AI breakthroughs within the next 18 months,
to Bloomberg.
Zhu Min, previously a deputy governor of the People‚Äôs Bank of China, made these remarks during the World Economic Forum in Tianjin.
He emphasized that these new software innovations ‚Äúwill fundamentally change the nature and the tech nature of the whole Chinese economy.‚Äù
The forecast is driven by China‚Äôs deep reservoir of engineering expertise, its enormous consumer market, and massive government investments in tech.
DeepSeek has become a poster child for Chinese AI ingenuity, offering models that rival OpenAI‚Äôs best at a fraction of the price.

As Zhu‚Äôs prediction suggests, DeepSeek is just the beginning ‚Äî if he‚Äôs right, we‚Äôre on the verge of a tidal wave of AI innovation from China. And this is all after semiconductor sanctions from the U.S., which are forcing them to operate at lower costs and under tight constraints.
Image source: Tesla
Just days after Tesla launched its robotaxi service in Austin, the¬†U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is reportedly
them over viral videos showing the vehicles behaving erratically on public roads.
Tesla just launched a limited rollout with 10 to 20 Model Ys equipped with the company‚Äôs latest FSD Unsupervised software and hardware.
Social media clips captured the robotaxis making erratic maneuvers, including entering oncoming traffic and stopping abruptly in the middle of roads.
NHTSA confirmed it is ‚Äúaware of the referenced incidents and is in contact with the manufacturer to gather additional information.‚Äù
The launch ‚Äî which includes a human valet in the front passenger seat ready to intervene if needed ‚Äî sparked an 8% spike in Tesla‚Äôs share price.

Tesla‚Äôs robotaxi launch arrives amid intense regulatory scrutiny, with the NHTSA already probing its Full Self-Driving tech after several serious crashes. For now, Waymo maintains a clear lead in the space, operating a large commercial fleet with over 250K weekly rides across multiple cities and a proven safety record.
